Alaska.mail_instructions: Request or fill out an absentee ballot application and send it to your local Absentee Office.
Alaska.in_person_instructions: Visit an early/in-person absentee voting location starting 15 days before the election.
Alaska.ballot_delivery: Postmarked or delivered by Election Day.

Alabama.mail_instructions: Request or fill out a ballot application and send it/take it to your local election manager.
Alabama.in_person_instructions: Delivered to your local election manager by 5 p.m. the day before the election.
Alabama.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're

  • Out of the country
  • Ill
  • Working a 10-hour shift
  • Caring for a family member who's confined to their home
  • Incarcerated (though not if you've been convicted of a felony)

Arkansas.mail_instructions: Request or download an absentee ballot application from your County Clerk.
Arkansas.in_person_instructions: Deliver your absentee ballot application by the day before the election.
Arkansas.ballot_delivery:
• In person: Before Election Day
  • By mail: Received by 7:30 p.m. on Election Day
Arkansas.requirements:
To vote absentee, you must:

  • Be unable to get to your polling site
  • ill
  • Have a physical disability
  • Indicate if you'll be picking you your ballot in person, by mail, or bearer (i.e. someone else is getting it for you)

Arizona.mail_instructions: Sign up online or contact your County Recorder to get added to AZ's "permanent early voting list."
Arizona.in_person_instructions: You can vote early in person starting 27 days before the election at an early voting location. Learn more about how and where.
Arizona.ballot_delivery: Election Day. You can return ballots to your County Recorder's Office, any voting location, or any designated ballot return box.

California.mail_instructions: Fill out a vote-by-mail application (or use the one that comes in your voter guide) and return it to your county elections office.
California.mail_request_deadline: 7 days before the election. If you miss this deadline, you can still apply in person. Some counties even let you apply by phone!
California.in_person_instructions: Some counties offer in-person early voting. Check with your county election office to find your county's early voting locations & times.
California.ballot_delivery: Postmarked or returned in person by Election Day.

Colorado.mail_instructions: You'll receive a mail ballot sent to the mailing address you listed when you registered.
Colorado.mail_request_deadline: You don't need to request a by-mail ballot in CO. They'll send it as long as you're registered.
Colorado.in_person_instructions: You can drop off your ballot in person before the election. Get in touch with your county clerk to learn where and when.
Colorado.ballot_delivery: Your county clerk must receive your ballot by 7 p.m. on Election Day.
Colorado.requirements: None (except that you're registered). (except that you're registered)..

Connecticut.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot application and send it to your town clerk.
Connecticut.mail_request_deadline: The CT Secretary of State isn't specific, but the state needs to process your application, send you a ballot, and receive your filled out ballot. Give yourself at least 10 days.
Connecticut.in_person_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot application and deliver it to your town clerk.
Connecticut.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're:

  • Out of town on Election Day
  • Ill
  • Celebrating a religious occasion that prevents you from voting
  • Physically incapable of getting to the polling place

Delaware.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot application and return it to your local Department of Elections.
Delaware.mail_request_deadline: Deleware stops issuing absentee ballots the day before the election. We recommend getting your ballot request in at least 10 days before the election.
Delaware.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: Fill out an absentee ballot application and bring it to your local Department of Elections.
Delaware.ballot_delivery: The last day to deliver an absentee ballot by hand is 12 days before the election. Your mailed ballot has to be in by the time the polls close on Election Day.
Delaware.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're:

  • Working
  • Away at school
  • Ill
  • On vacation
  • Physically unable to get to the polls
  • Celebrating a religious occasion that prevents you from voting

Florida.mail_instructions: Download or request a vote-by-mail application from your county Supervisor of Elections and then send it back.
Florida.in_person_instructions: As long as you're registered, you can vote early in person at an early voting site.
Florida.ballot_delivery:
• By-mail ballots must be returned by 7 p.m. on Election Day
  • In-person early voting happens from 10 to 3 days before an election. The period may be longer in your area; check with your county Supervisor of Elections

Georgia.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot application and mail/email/take it back to your local County Board of Registrar's Office.
Georgia.mail_request_deadline: The GA Secretary of State doesn't specify exactly when you need to return your application, but leave enough time to submit your application, receive your ballot, and send it back. We recommend at least 10 days before the election.
Georgia.in_person_instructions: During the early voting period, you can vote at one of these early vote locations. The early voting period starts 4 Mondays before the election and ends the Friday before Election Day. You'll fill out an absentee ballot at the early vote location.

Hawaii.mail_instructions: Your local election clerk will mail you a ballot and an envelope to return it in.
Hawaii.mail_request_deadline: You don't need to request a by-mail ballot in HI. They'll send it as long as you're registered.
Hawaii.in_person_instructions: You can register and vote early at a voter service center starting 10 days before the election. (Hawaii next publishes voter service center locations & times in May 2020.)

Iowa.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot application and mail, email, fax, or take it to your county auditor.
Iowa.mail_request_deadline:
If you're requesting a ballot through the mail:

  • For the general election: 10 days before
  • For other elections: 11 days before

If you're requesting a ballot by email or fax, submit your application the Monday before the election.
Iowa.in_person_instructions: Starting 29 days before an election, you can vote at your county auditor's office until the day before an election.
Iowa.ballot_delivery: By the time the polls close on Election Day.

Idaho.mail_instructions: Fill out this absentee ballot application and send it to your county clerk.
Idaho.in_person_instructions: You can cast an early vote at an "absent elector's polling place" (ask your county clerk where this is) until 5 p.m. on the Friday before an election. The beginning of this early voting period seems to vary by county; check with your local clerk for specifics.

Illinois.mail_instructions: Apply for a by-mail ballot online through your your county clerk, and you'll get a ballot in the mail. Return it to the clerk when you've filled it out.
Illinois.in_person_instructions: You can vote in person at an early voting location starting 15 days before an election.
Illinois.ballot_delivery: Return your ballot by Election Day.

Indiana.mail_instructions: The bottom of this Indiana Secretary of State webpage includes forms for mail and in-person absentee voting. Fill one out and mail it to your county election board.
Indiana.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: Fill out the in-person applicaton and take it to your county election board.
Indiana.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're:

  • Away or working while the polls are open (6 a.m until 6 pm)
  • Physically unable to get to the polls
  • 65 years or older
  • Ill, injured, or caring for someone else who is
  • Celebrating a religious occasion that prevents you from voting
  • In an address confidentiality program
  • In the military or public safety
  • A "serious sex offender" per Indiana's law.
  • Have no way to get to the polls

Kansas.mail_instructions: Fill out an advance vote application or request one and return it to your county elections office.
Kansas.in_person_instructions: You can vote in person before the election at your county elections office. Advance voting start dates vary by county.
Kansas.ballot_delivery: Received no later than 3 days after the election.

Kentucky.mail_instructions: Request an absentee application from your country clerk.
Kentucky.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: Visit your country clerk and request an application.
Kentucky.ballot_delivery: Mail your ballot back by 6 p.m. on Election Day. Check with your county clerk to see when you can return your in-person absentee ballot.
Kentucky.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're:

  • Ill
  • Elderly
  • A student who's out of the country
  • Outside of the state but eligible to vote
  • Incarcerated but not convicted
  • Working on Election Day while the polls are open

Louisiana.mail_instructions: Submit an application to your registrar of voters. You can also apply through LA's online system.
Louisiana.in_person_instructions: Go to your local Registrars of Voters Office to vote early.
Louisiana.ballot_delivery:
• In person: You can vote early between 14 and 7 days before the election
  • By mail: 4:30 p.m. the day before the election
.
Louisiana.requirements:
You can vote early for any reason. You can vote by mail if you're:

  • 65 years old or older
  • Live or work away from home
  • Incarcerated by not convicted
  • Physically incapable of getting to the polls
.

Massachusetts.mail_instructions: Download (or request) and fill out an absentee ballot application from your county clerk.
Massachusetts.mail_request_deadline: By 12 p.m. on the day before the election. If the day before is a holiday or a Sunday, then by 5 p.m. on the last business day before the election.
Massachusetts.in_person_instructions: The Secretary of State mostly gives instructions for absentee by-mail voting, but in-person absentee voting is possible, too. Get in touch with your county clerk and ask how.
Massachusetts.ballot_delivery: By the time the polls close on Election Day.
Massachusetts.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're:

  • Out of the state on Election Day
  • Physically incapable of getting to the polls
  • Religious beliefs prevent you from voting
.

Maryland.mail_instructions: Request an absentee ballot online or download the application and return it to your local board of elections.
Maryland.mail_request_deadline:
• A week before the election if you want your ballot by mail or fax
  • 4 days before the election if you'll be downloading it through MD's online system
Maryland.in_person_instructions: You can vote early at an early voting center. Check this MD Board of Elections page for when you can vote early in 2020.
Maryland.ballot_delivery: Your mailed ballot has to be postmarked by the election and received no later than 10 days after the election.

Michigan.mail_instructions: Download an application (or request one) and return it to your town clerk.
Michigan.mail_request_deadline: By 5 p.m. the Friday before an election.
Michigan.in_person_instructions: The in-person request deadline is later than the by-mail deadline: You can get an absentee application at your town clerk's office until 4 p.m. the day before an election.

Minnesota.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot application and return it to your county elections office.
Minnesota.mail_request_deadline: The deadline is the day before the election, but if you're mailing your ballot, make sure you leave time to receive it and return it by the deadline.
Minnesota.in_person_instructions: Go to your county election office to register and vote early. There may be other early voting locations, too; check with your local office to find out more.
Minnesota.ballot_delivery:
• By mail: On Election Day
  • In person early voting locations open more than a month before the election
Minnesota.requirements: None to apply, but you'll need a witness when you're filling out the ballot.

Montana.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot application and send it to your county elections office.
Montana.mail_request_deadline: Noon the day before the election.
Montana.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: Fill out an absentee ballot application and send/take it to your county elections office. If you're it dropping off in person, you can pick up your ballot right then.

Mississippi.mail_instructions: Contact your county/municipal clerk. They will probably have you fill out an absentee ballot form like this one.
Mississippi.mail_request_deadline: We couldn't find an official absentee ballot request deadline, but leave enough time to get your ballot, fill it out, and return it by the absentee voting deadline.
Mississippi.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: Go to your county/municipal clerk's office and apply to vote absentee.
Mississippi.ballot_delivery:
• In person: 3 days before the election
  • By mail: Postmarked by election day
Mississippi.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're

  • Elderly
  • Ill
  • Working
  • Out of the state for school

Missouri.mail_instructions: Request an absentee ballot from your local election authority. You can ask them to mail you a request form, or download this request form and return it via email, mail, or fax.
Missouri.mail_request_deadline: 2 Wednesdays before the election by 5 p.m.
Missouri.in_person_instructions: Go to your local election authority to vote an absentee ballot beginning 6 weeks before an election.
Missouri.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're

  • Il
  • Physically incapable of getting the the polls
  • Working
  • Out of the state
  • Celebrating a religious occasion that prevents you from voting
  • Incarcerated but not prevented from voting (e.g. you were convicted of a felony)
  • Part of an address confidentiality program

North Carolina.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot request form and send/take it to your county board of elections.
North Carolina.mail_request_deadline: 5 p.m. on the Tuesday before the election.
North Carolina.in_person_instructions: You can register and vote the same day at an early voting location.
North Carolina.ballot_delivery: Your county board of elections must receive your mailed ballot by 5 p.m. on Election Day.

North Dakota.mail_instructions: You can submit an application online to your county auditor's office. You could also download the ballot request form, fill it out, and email/mail/take it back to them.
North Dakota.in_person_instructions: Find out about in-person early voting locations online or contact your county auditor's office.
North Dakota.ballot_delivery: We couldn't find an official deadline. We recommend applying for a mail ballot at least 2 weeks in advance, or following the early vote in-person instructions.

New Hampshire.mail_instructions: You'll need to fill out an absentee ballot request and send or email it to your town clerk.
New Hampshire.mail_request_deadline: There's no deadline, but leave time for the clerk to receive and process your request, send you a ballot, and then receive your completed ballot.
New Hampshire.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: You'll need to fill out an absentee ballot request and send it to your town clerk.
New Hampshire.ballot_delivery:
• By mail: By Election Day at your Clerk's Office (or on Election Day to your polling place)
  • In person: The day before the election at your Clerk's Office
New Hampshire.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're:

  • Physically incapable of getting to the polls
  • Celebrating a religious occasion that prevents you from voting
  • Away from home on Election Day
  • Working, including caring for children or "infirm" adults

Nebraska.mail_instructions: Fill out an early voting form and send, fax, or email it to your county elections office.
Nebraska.mail_request_deadline: 2 Fridays before the election by 6 p.m.
Nebraska.in_person_instructions: You can vote in person at your county elections office starting 30 days before a general election and 15 days before any other election. The last day to early vote is the day before the election.
Nebraska.ballot_delivery: By the time the polls close on Election Day.

New Jersey.mail_instructions: Send a vote-by-mail application to your county clerk. You can find your county's application here.
New Jersey.in_person_instructions: You can apply in-person to vote early until 3 p.m. the day before the election at your county clerk's office.
New Jersey.ballot_delivery: Postmarked by the election and received within 2 days of the polls closing.

New Mexico.mail_instructions: Request an absentee ballot online or your county clerk.
New Mexico.in_person_instructions: In 2020, you can vote early at your county clerk's office between Oct. 17 and Oct. 31

Nevada.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot request form and submit it to your local clerk or election official. Clark County residents can request a ballot online.
Nevada.in_person_instructions: There's a 2-week period during which you can vote early at an early voting location.

New York.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot request application and send it to your county board of elections.
New York.mail_request_deadline: Postmarked 5 days before the election (though you have to postmark the ballot itself by the day before, so don't wait this long!).
New York.in_person_instructions: You can vote early from 9 to 2 days before the election at an early vote locations. You can also ask your county board of elections about places and times to early vote.
New York.ballot_delivery: Postmarked the day before the election. It can also be delivered by hand by someone else on Election Day.
New York.requirements:
You don't need a reason to vote early in person. You can vote absentee by mail if you're:

  • Away from home on Election Day
  • Ill or physically incapable of getting to the polls
  • Caring for someone who is ill or incapable of getting to the polls
  • A resident or patient of the Veterans Health Administration Hospital
  • Incarcerated but not convincted of a felony

Ohio.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot request and send it to your county board of elections to vote early.
Ohio.in_person_instructions: As soon as voter registration is over (see deadlines above!), you can go to your county board of elections to vote early.
Ohio.ballot_delivery: Return your ballot to your board of elections by 7:30 p.m. on Election Day or make sure it's postmarked the day before Election Day.

Oklahoma.mail_instructions:
Apply online to vote absentee or download a ballot request form and send it to your County Board of Elections. You can also just write a letter. Include your name, date of birth, address you're registered at, mailing address, election you're registering for, and either a signature or copy of your ID.

For either method: You'll need to get your signature notarized or include a copy of your ID.
Oklahoma.mail_request_deadline: 5 p.m. on the Wednesday before the election. Don't forget to include a notarized signature or attach a copy of your ID.
Oklahoma.in_person_instructions: You can vote early at your County Board of Elections on the Thursday and Friday before elections from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. For state and national elections, you can also vote on Saturday from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m.

Oregon.mail_instructions: If you're registered, you'll get a ballot 2-3 weeks before the election. Mail it to a ballot drop box location anywhere in the state.
Oregon.mail_request_deadline: You don't need to request a mail ballot in Oregon. They'll send you one as long as you're registered.
Oregon.in_person_instructions: You'll get a ballot 2-3 weeks before the election. Take it to a ballot drop box location.
Oregon.requirements: If for some reason you're not able to pick up your ballot, you can still request an absentee ballot online, or download the ballot request form and return it to your elections office.

Pennsylvania.mail_instructions: Apply online for an absentee ballot. You can also download an absentee ballot request form, fill it out, and send it to your county elections office.
Pennsylvania.in_person_instructions: You can apply to vote absentee in person at your county elections office.
Pennsylvania.requirements:
You can vote by mail if you're registered. You can vote absentee in person if you're:

  • Away for school, work, or vacation
  • Physically incapable of getting the polls
  • Celebrating a religious occasion that prevents you from voting on Election Day
  • Incarcerated but not convicted of a felony

Rhode Island.mail_instructions: Download a mail ballot application (RI's Secretary of State will post the right form before each election) and send it to your Board of Canvassers. Note: You'll send the ballot itself to the Board of Elections.
Rhode Island.in_person_instructions: Download a mail ballot application and send/deliver it to your Board of Canvassers. Then, deliver your filled-out ballot to the Board of Elections.

South Carolina.mail_instructions: Fill out an online absentee ballot request or ask your county voter registration office to email/send you one. Fill it out and email/fax/send it back to your county office.
South Carolina.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: Fill out an online absentee ballot request or ask your county voter registration office to email/send you one. Then, deliver it to your county office.
South Carolina.ballot_delivery: Your county elections office needs to receive your ballot by 7 p.m. on Election Day.
South Carolina.requirements:
You can vote absentee if you're:
  • Living outside the county you're registered in
  • Physically incapable of getting to the polls
  • Caring for someone who's ill or immobilized
  • Working on Election Day and can't get to the polls
  • Temporarily away from home (e.g. on vacation) on Election Day
  • On jury duty
  • Grieving a family member's passing away within 3 days of the election
  • Incarcerated but not convicted
  • 65 years old or older
  • Celebrating a religious occasion that prevents you from voting

South Dakota.mail_instructions: Request or fill out an absentee ballot application and send it to your county election official.
South Dakota.mail_request_deadline: Your county election official must receive your application by 5 p.m. the day before the election.
South Dakota.in_person_instructions: You'll request a ballot by mail or fill out a ballot online. Then, you can deliver it to your county election official during the absentee voting period (which begins about 45 days before each election).

Tennessee.mail_title: Vote early by mail (if you meet certain requirements)
Tennessee.mail_instructions:
Request an mail ballot from you county election commission. You can fill out the online form, or you can write a letter with the following information:

  • Name
  • Address you're registered at
  • Your social security number
  • Your date of birth
  • Mailing address
  • The election you want to vote absentee by mail in
  • If the election is a primary: Which political party's primary you want to participate in
  • Reason for voting by mail (see requirements)
  • Yout signature
Tennessee.in_person_instructions: Get in touch with your county election commission and find out when and where you can vote early in person. The early voting period is usually from 20 to 5 days before an election.
Tennessee.ballot_delivery: By the time polls close on Election Day.
Tennessee.requirements:
You can vote by mail if you're:

  • Away from the county you're registered in during the early voting period and all day on Election Day (e.g. for school, work, etc.)
  • Your doctor files a statement with the county election commission at least 7 days before the election that says you're physically incapable of in-person voting
  • Physically incapable of getting to the polls (note: TN lists this and the previous item separately. It's not clear if they should actually be the same, or if the difference is people who are temporarily immobilized vs. always immobilized. If you think either might apply to you, check with your county election commission.)
  • Caring for someone who is ill or physically incapable of getting to the polls
  • You live outside the county you're registered in
  • On jury duty
  • 60 years old or older
  • Running for office in the election
  • Celebrating a religious occasion that prevents you from voting in person during early voting or on Election Day

Texas.mail_instructions: Fill out an absentee ballot request form or complete a request online and send it back to your county clerk or elections official.
Texas.in_person_instructions: You can usually vote early in person from 24 to 4 days before the election. You can find early voting locations on Texas's state website.
Texas.requirements:
You can vote absentee by mail if you're

  • 65 years or older
  • Physically incapable of getting to the polls
  • Away from home
  • Incarcerated not convicted of a felony

Utah.mail_instructions: Request a mail ballot online or download the request form and mail it to your county clerk.
Utah.in_person_instructions: You can vote early, usually starting 2 weeks before the election. Here's an online tool to find locations and dates.
Utah.ballot_delivery: Postmarked the day before the election. You can also drop it off in person at a polling location, clerk's office, or a ballot drop box.

Virginia.mail_instructions: You can apply online for an absentee ballot, or you can download the form and send it to your local registrar.
Virginia.mail_request_deadline: Return your ballot request by 5 p.m. the Tuesday before the election by mail, fax, or email. If you miss this deadline, you can still go in person to apply and vote until the Saturday before the election.
Virginia.in_person_instructions: Starting 45 days before the election, you can go to your local registrar and vote. It's a good idea to review the ballot application before you get there make sure you have everything you need.
Virginia.ballot_delivery: We couldn't find a deadline. Aim to mail your absentee ballot back for before Election Day, or vote in-person absentee.
Virginia.requirements: If you're a first-time voter, you'll have to give a reason to absentee vote. These include illness, being away at school, pregnancy, temporarily living out of the U.S., you or your spouse is an active duty service member, you're confined awaiting trial, or you're 65 years old or more.

Vermont.mail_instructions: Request an early ballot online or download the request form and send it to your town clerk.
Vermont.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: Request an early ballot online or download the request form and take it to your town clerk.
Vermont.ballot_delivery: The day before the election (or to the polling place on Election Day).

Washington.mail_instructions: Every voter receives a mail ballot sent to the mailing address they listed when they registered.
Washington.mail_request_deadline: You don't need to request a by-mail ballot in WA. They'll send one as long as you're registered.
Washington.in_person_instructions: If you'd rather vote in person, you can go to a voting center or to your county's elections department.
Washington.ballot_delivery: Postmark your ballot or return it to a ballot dropbox by Election Day.

Washington, D.C..mail_instructions: Download an absentee ballot request application and send it to the D.C. Board of Elections.
Washington, D.C..mail_request_deadline: Contact the D.C. Board of Elections to find out when the request deadline is.
Washington, D.C..in_person_instructions: You can vote at an Early Voting Center

Wisconsin.mail_instructions: You can request an absentee ballot online, or you can download a ballot request form and return it to your municipal clerk.
Wisconsin.mail_request_deadline: 5 p.m. on the Thursday before the election.
Wisconsin.in_person_instructions: In-person early voting is different town-by-town in WI. Contact your municipal clerk to learn about places/times near you.
Wisconsin.ballot_delivery: Received by 8 p.m. on Election Day.

West Virginia.mail_instructions: Send an absentee ballot application to the office of your county clerk.
West Virginia.in_person_instructions: According to WV's Secretary of State, you can vote early in person between the 13th and 3rd days before the election at "the county courthouse, annex or designated community voting location".
West Virginia.requirements:
You can vote absentee if WV if you're

  • Ill or injured
  • Elderly
  • Incarcerated but not convicted of a felony
  • Away from home, e.g. for work or school
  • Living outside the county where you're registered to vote

Wyoming.mail_instructions: Request an absentee ballot from your county clerk.
Wyoming.mail_request_deadline: We couldn't find a deadline, but make sure there's enought time for your clerk to send you a ballot and for you to return it by the deadline (Election Day).
Wyoming.in_person_instructions: Same as by mail: Request an absentee ballot from your county clerk.
